results.title: The Vision of William Blake (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Morse Films, British Film Institute Experimental Film Fund and Guy Brenton
results.brief_description: Filmed in four museums that contain major collections of Blake’s writings and paintings, this documentary by Guy Brenton explores the anguish of Blake’s prophetic world, Music by Ralph Vaughan Williams, and narration and poems read by Bernard Miles and Robert Speight.

results.title: Just Peanuts
results.brief_description: In Australia, peanuts are grown at Kingaroy, Queensland. The film shows how they reach down from the stalks to grow under the soil, how they are harvested and left to dry in the hot sun. The many uses of peanuts are illustrated, including the surprising number of by-products such as fabrics, coffee substitute, cosmetics and high quality soap.

results.title: A Scary Time
results.creator_credit: UNICEF, Thorold Dickinson, Shirley Clarke and Robert Hughes
results.brief_description: A powerful emotional plea by the United Nation’s Children Fund, appealing for support from affluent nations using experimental film techniques combining found and improvised footage. The film intercuts footage of American children during their Halloween ‘Trick or Treat’ rounds collecting money for UNICEF with footage of international child hunger. Deals convincingly with the realities of children’s lives in less affluent countries. Music by Peggy Glanville-Hicks.

results.title: Gippsland Honeymoon
results.brief_description:
A honeymoon couple tour the Gippsland area and admire the scenic attractions of the country-side. Depicts many of Victoria’s famous tourist attractions including: Lakes Entrance, Gippsland, Orbost, the Snowy River, the Tambo River, Bairnsdale, Omeo, Walhalla Goldfields, Buchan Caves, Mallacoota Inlet, La Trobe Valley, Glen Maggie Weir and Ninety Mile Beach. Produced in conjunction with The Tourist Development Authority and The Gippsland Lakes and Tourist Promotion Council.

This film was discussed on ABC Gippsland Radio on 14 March 2020. The following are comments for viewers which add insight into the film

Martin Richardson “Joe” is Joe Southon, from Paynesville who wasn’t actually a Lakes Entrance fisherman, but was the chosen “talent” for the movie - it was through his connections that the film crew came down here to make the movie. He was a farmer, part-time fisherman, and farm manager whose property occupied a large part of what is now the town of Paynesville. He was also involved in many civic roles around the Bairnsdale Shire. His daughter Beryl and son Bluey still live in Paynesville.

Ashley Meek My father features on this add fishing at the Glenmaggie spillway

Neil Walters who picked up one of the narrators was Ross Higgins. “put the money on the fridge wog.!” (Kingswood Country)

Graeme Nixon Cape Conran my dad jim nixon boat and me. Front boat

results.title: Passing Era of the Steam Horse
results.brief_description: Steam locomotives have been replaced by diesels on the Victorian Railways. Their history in the system is briefly covered, and various types are shown in operation, concluding with the narrow gauge service from Ferntree Gully to Gembrook being restored as a tourist feature.

results.title: Leaf
results.brief_description: Captures the spirit of Autumn in the wilderness, by blending the elements of wind and leaf in a visually and rhythmically enchanting study of California’s Yosemite valley.

results.title: Waistlines and lifelines
results.creator_credit: Advent Films, John Banks and Russell Gibbs
results.brief_description: Ron has a weight problem. He tries massage and the crash diet, but to no avail. A heart attack scare sends him to his doctor, who recommends graded exercises and consultation with a dietician.

results.title: Stamina
results.brief_description: A film illustrating the manufacture of Stamina trousers and showing the care exercised in all stages. The various processes are shown together with a brief history of men’s dress and the sewing machine.
